title: Bishnupur Terracotta
hero_image_alt: Detailed terracotta panels on a temple wall
short_description: Famous for the intricate terracotta temples and the 'Bankura Horse', a symbol of Bengali folk art.
long_description:
Bishnupur in West Bengal is famed for its terracotta temples built by the Malla kings in the 17th and 18th centuries. Since stone was scarce in the alluvial plains of Bengal, artisans turned to the abundant clay to create bricks and decorative panels. 

The Bankura Horse, with its long erect neck and pointed ears, is the most famous product of this region and serves as the logo of Indian handicrafts. The craft involves creating hollow figures (for easier firing) and intricate relief work depicting scenes from the Ramayana, Mahabharata, and social life.
motifs_and_meanings: Horse: Symbol of devotion (often offered to village deities).

major_centres.title: Panchmura Village
major_centres.summary: The hub of Bankura Horse makers.

shipping_and_packaging_tips: Bankura horses have fragile ears and tails. Crate shipping advised for large ones.
authenticity_tips: Real terracotta has a distinct reddish-orange burnt earth color.
local_economy_note: A primary livelihood for the Kumbhakar caste in the region.
